document.title: 2021 Minnesota K12 Academic Standards in Social Studies Final

A19686207F6B4CFA8515B6ED4293F912.description:
Explore the history of surveillance and oversight in early
America and examine their ties to contemporary systems and
structures of surveillance and oversight.

71DC2A7988AC42C4B8E43D62858AED49.description:
Ways of Knowing and
Methodologies: Use ethnic and
Indigenous studies methods and
sources in order to understand
the roots of contemporary
systems of oppression and apply
lessons from the past that could
eliminate historical and
contemporary injustices.

95A3A433DC0C49A2AF66EB9577BDABDA.description:
Analyze anti-colonial and anti-racist resistance movements of
culturally, racially and ethnically diverse people throughout the
world.

4A109C562F7F49889BD92BDFF7DD9AB6.description:
Resistance: Describe how
individuals and communities have
fought for freedom and liberation
against systemic and coordinated
exercises of power locally and
globally. Identify strategies or
times that have resulted in lasting
change. Organize with others to
engage in activities that could
further the rights and dignity of
all.

73B9E1E3C0FD4BA38B87CFFD9E8767A2.description:
Investigate name origins, identity and how language can be
exclusionary and liberatory.

05D6474B84824576A465A5B75EAF7AC6.description:
Identity: Analyze the ways
power and language construct
the social identities of race,
religion, geography, ethnicity,
and gender. Apply these
understandings to one’s own
social identities and other groups
living in Minnesota, centering
those whose stories and histories
have been marginalized, erased,
or ignored.

35698D05ED6A421D9782E9C0023D9424.description:
Describe Indigenous efforts today to revitalize and reclaim
Indigenous languages, traditions and sovereignty.

2F565DC99FBF433C94A69D45EE2DC436.description:
Connecting Past and Present:
Use historical methods and
sources to identify and analyze
the roots of a contemporary
issue. Design a plan to address it.

2EC270C9697045D4BB93F16B2A3B4193.description:
Explain the difference between indentured servitude and
chattel slavery in colonial North America and identify the
transatlantic slave route on a map.

772C588B58984606ADC3E7389FB754CE.description:
Causation and
Argumentation: Integrate
evidence from multiple historical
sources and interpretations into a
reasoned argument or compelling
narrative about the past.

BA38D66127A04241AF2C2DF9DF8FB028.description:
Explain the religious, political and economic reasons for the
movement of people from Europe to the Americas and examine
the impact of colonization and settler colonialism on Indigenous
peoples.

D903EE1F43A9412C99B5D9D480B33FEF.description:
Causation and
Argumentation: Integrate
evidence from multiple historical
sources and interpretations into a
reasoned argument or compelling
narrative about the past.

9264DB15493048988EFE369EC2B6E620.description:
Analyze a primary source from the Revolutionary era by
interpreting the historical context, intended audience, purpose
and author’s point of view and identifying what perspectives
and narratives are absent from the source.

7B01E55FBFDB48B8B526117BA126BB8E.description:
Historical Sources and
Evidence: Investigate a variety of
historical sources by: a) analyzing
primary and secondary sources;
b) identifying perspectives and
narratives that are absent from
the available sources; and c)
interpreting the historical
context, intended audience,
purpose, and author’s point of
view of these sources.

6E2FDB4F98EE4D5480E747CAC68F02D8.description:
Identify examples of self-government and sovereignty before
the United States became a country by examining multiple
primary sources, including Indigenous sources.

8F41D2B0A1D5469DB4C840A5E463202F.description:
Historical Sources and
Evidence: Investigate a variety of
historical sources by: a) analyzing
primary and secondary sources;
b) identifying perspectives and
narratives that are absent from
the available sources; and c)
interpreting the historical
context, intended audience,
purpose, and author’s point of
view of these sources.

18C018E8865C45009B76A9016AFD1A27.description:
Explain an event or events of the American Revolution through
multiple perspectives.

A2706C6426CA4C77938654808298371B.description:
Historical Perspectives:
Identify diverse points of view,
and describe how one’s frame of
reference influences historical
perspective.

811A4C0967AC4A71AC499013E2F964A2.description:
Describe ways that enslaved people and people in free Black
communities resisted slavery and transferred, developed and
maintained their cultural identities.

8DC30FE1A25D45F8800DB7C500F74B91.description:
Historical Perspectives:
Identify diverse points of view,
and describe how one’s frame of
reference influences historical
perspective.

EB9AF58831EC44529747056C20E468D6.description:
Compare and contrast the impact of the American Revolution
on different groups within the 13 colonies that made up the
new United States and identify what narratives are absent.

A1D21F33597F4E9388EEABAB54D268DA.description:
Context, Change, and
Continuity: Ask historical
questions about context, change
and continuity in order to identify
and analyze dominant and nondominant narratives about the
past.

1A87107439E64647988DF23D627E4B8A.description:
Identify at least three Indigenous nations in North America.
Describe the social structures, political systems and economic
activities of at least one Indigenous nation.

787FD0504DB64DACA639FC90D9D16F65.description:
Context, Change, and
Continuity: Ask historical
questions about context, change
and continuity in order to identify
and analyze dominant and nondominant narratives about the
past.

4ADB0E25027442D1982E0A73BC8A9B84.description:
Analyze how different perspectives influenced past decisions to
name places and impact changing place names today.

3BCC774A9EB54CEEA13664D4C0D8C1E9.description:
Culture: Investigate how
sense of place is impacted by
different cultural perspectives.

BB08752327A9414D9C61E91E27EDC304.description:
Describe how the choices people make have impacted a
physical environment over time.

A674E59185694624B031435B40F51FD2.description:
Human-Environment
Interaction: Evaluate the
relationship between humans
and the environment, including
climate change.

D9EF512C447F425E8D4559C9B173226F.description:
Describe interconnectedness and identify patterns within what
became the United States, considering past, present and future
trends.

A61106F9C752497D8770B04862CD8F99.description:
Human Systems: Analyze
patterns of movement and
interconnectedness within and
between cultural, economic and
political systems from a local to
global scale.

92D31C9001A14B688BDDF3D80B9C2CD6.description:
Explain how physical and human characteristics and power
structures are used to create regions on the land.

C5EB53AA5DF549D989A042DAECDB7B73.description:
Places and Regions: Describe
places and regions, explaining
how they are influenced by
power structures.

46136E8A757A4BABBF210209E28881A4.description:
Investigate spatial problems and then act by communicating
conclusions with authentic audiences.

BE0928AEF46D4876BE201583B33E4772.description:
Geospatial Skills and Inquiry:
Apply geographic tools, including
geospatial technologies, and
geographic inquiry to solve
spatial problems.

0D264A06195E435BA2187AE064D32F41.description:
Create and interpret both fixed and dynamic maps that
represent the same places in early America from different
perspectives and times.

EFC8AE838E964B10B956BAACEE546E54.description:
Geospatial Skills and Inquiry:
Apply geographic tools, including
geospatial technologies, and
geographic inquiry to solve
spatial problems.

2C1D1B1592AF47D9B56277B1C44331B8.description:
Explain how government decisions concerning trading
relationships may impact people differently within a community
or nation.

53C497422964485BBCA3EFB0E4EED484.description:
Global and International:
Explain why people trade and
why nations encourage or limit
trade. Analyze the costs and
benefits of international trade
and globalization on communities
and the environment.

D47ED57282954B9C8D43DE2D63991A80.description:
Investigate the relationship between individual well-being and
the well-being of an entire community or nation.

12D2D59A28404A349A10801E48744CF6.description:
Macroeconomics: Measure
and evaluate the well-being of
nations and communities using a
variety of indicators. Explain the
causes of economic ups and
downs. Evaluate how
government actions affect a
nation’s economy and
individuals’ well-being within an
economy.

D0B5ACB3C9364C26A0B240AFC46BBFB3.description:
Calculate profit as the difference between revenue (from selling
goods and services) and cost (payments for resources used).

B199D73797D246FA9737D412D7F1D207.description:
Microeconomics: Explain and
evaluate how resources are used
and how goods and services are
distributed within different
economic systems. Analyze how
incentives influence the decisions
of consumers, producers, and
governments. Evaluate the
intended and unintended
consequences of these decisions
from multiple perspectives.

898BAE4EA1AE4A49B9167992F0A8BC61.description:
Apply a decision-making process to identify alternative options
available to decision-makers in a historical setting, the decision
that was made and the opportunity cost of the decision.

29D86479EECB478696F6AE5193CB720D.description:
Personal Finance: Apply
economic concepts and models
to develop individual and
collective financial goals and
strategies for achieving these
goals, taking into consideration
historical and contemporary
conditions that either inhibit or
advance the creation of individual
and generational wealth.

FC9AD6AC9BDD4AB297A8E690AA2CD824.description:
Describe a U.S. Federal Indian policy and explain how it impacts
tribal nation self-determination and agency.

2F78303D28694D9497C7C85AB638B358.description:
Tribal Nations: Evaluate the
unique political status, trust
relationships and governing
structures of sovereign Tribal
Nations and the United States.

EC4CEA0B7EA44E8B9341E4471C596F51.description:
Describe how the U.S. Constitution establishes the three
branches of government, how leaders are selected, and how
governmental power is limited through the principles of
federalism, separation of powers, and checks and balances.

A5EFE5693353439BB3B45015F8B42AA6.description:
Governmental Institutions and
Political Processes: Explain and
evaluate processes, rules and
laws of United States
governmental institutions at
local, state and federal levels and
within Tribal Nations.

809958A6212B4D9CB468C5DD2E2C83BB.description:
Explain specific protections that the Bill of Rights provides to
individuals and the importance of these 10 amendments to the
ratification of the U.S. Constitution.

B42482131B704C46B72F13CF6FEE5E58.description:
Rights and Responsibilities:
Explain and evaluate rights,
duties and responsibilities in
democratic society.

F9F762E275574D47854AC0C8A95BD7C9.description:
Identify a democratic principle written in the Declaration of
Independence and the preamble to the U.S. Constitution and
describe how the principle impacts the decisions of
government, society or communities.

FA9FC591A6C640FB84A4550A3269C8F3.description:
Democratic Values and
Principles: Explain democratic
values and principles that guide
governments, societies and
communities. Analyze the
tensions within the United States
constitutional government.
